newsitem.title: USA: U.S. Plains fed cattle quiet, no sales - feedlots.
newsitem.headline: U.S. Plains fed cattle quiet, no sales - feedlots.

text.p: U.S. Plains fed cattle markets were quiet early Monday, with no reported bids or sales, feedlot sources said.
Owners were pricing cattle at $66.00 to $67.00 per cwt, following heavy trading last week mostly at $65.00, they said.
Packers were comfortable with live inventories after last week's big sales and will take their time buying, they said.

"There's a few buyers out in the lot checking inventory and I wouldn't be surprised to see them bid $63.00 to $64.00, but I don't expect to see anything trade at those levels," a Kansas feedlot manager said.
Sales last week depleted showlists and near the second largest trading day record in Kansas on Wednesday.

Attempts at trading higher this week could be restrained by Friday's bearishly-construed USDA monthly Cattle on Feed Report, market sources said. The data showed many more cattle on feed as of August 1 than expected and July placements well above trade expectations.

USDA said in the seven key cattle feeding states, the number of cattle in feedlots with capacities of 1,000 head or more had 19 percent more cattle on feed than a year earlier, while July placements were up 18 percent from a year earlier.
Weakness from the report could offset potential support from higher beef prices late last week, the sources said.
